Award.AwardTitle: I-Corps: Real-time characterization using in-line angular scatterometry during high-speed roll-to-roll fabrication processes
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this I-Corps project provides real-time measurements to optimize yield and reduce waste in novel roll-to-roll (R2R) manufacturing processes. The proposed high-speed technology can perform the critical non-contact, real-time measurements without interfering with high-speed R2R fabrication processes. Commonly used analytical tools use statistical analysis procedures; none of them can be implemented during real-time R2R fabrication systems due to their large-size and vacuum conditions. The proposed technology closes the gap between new fabrication processes and systems that measure in real time.

This I-Corps project focuses on the commercialization of metrology technology for novel fabrication processes used in nano-technology products (e.g. nano-imprint lithography, roll-to-roll, and wafer-scale). The proposed in-line optical angular scatterometer provides real-time metrology without interfering with fabrication processes. Optical Angular Scatterometry offers enough resolution to characterize structures down to approximately 20 nm and 24 nm (pitch size) for pattern metallic and photoresist nanostructures. Projections of sensitivity show enough resolution and sensitivity for dimensions down to approximately 10 nm. The proposed scatterometer system has been demonstrated on a moving substrate at a speed of 50 cm/s, well above currently projected roll-to-roll manufacturing speeds. Various 1D, 2D, and 3D patterns have been studied in good agreement with both static off-line scatterometers and SEM measurements.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
Final Project Report

NSF Award # 2041676

I-Corps: Real-time characterization using in-line angular scatterometry during high-speed roll-to-roll fabrication processes

 

Team: NanoMetrology

PI/Entreperneur Lead (EL) - Juan Jose Faria Briceno,Univeristy of New Mexico

Co-PI/Technical Lead (TL) - Steven RJ Brueck, University of New Mexico

Industrial Lead (IL) - Scot Moye, Palladin  

Introduction:

Roughly 20% of the processes in high-volume IC fabrication focus on metrology. New fabrication techniques such as roll-to-roll (R2R) processes are being developed for manufacturing large-area nanotechnology products such as wire-grid polarizers (WGP), metal-mesh grids, and metamaterials. Angular Scatterometry has demonstrated noncontact, optical capabilities for characterizing WGP and photoresist structures with sub-100 nm dimensions, with simulations extending to ~ 10 nm. This work focuses on closing the gap between new fabrication processes: Roll-to-Roll/Roll-to-Sheet (R2R/R2S), and metrology/inspection systems capable of characterizing samples (flat, 1D, 2D, and 3D) in real-time during advanced nanomanufacturing. R2R and R2S are advanced new, low-cost, high-volume manufacturing approaches to nanoscale features. Due to the dynamic conditions during production, real-time, in-line metrology/inspection processes are fundamental to ensuring yield and production efficiency. We were able to develop a full market analysis to determine if our metrology/inspection system had a place on the current manufacturing market place.

Overview of the Project:

We participated in the National NSF-ICORP program. We worked to develop our value proposition based on feedback from potential customers, channel players, and partners. During the ICORP program, we completed +110 interviews with: potential customers, experts, and potential partners. Also, we were able to develop a full Business Model Canvas analysis with a clear, data driven understanding of the R2R/R2S market needs. We developed a full value proposition, identifying direct (partner) customer segments, identifying channels and customer relationship strategies, while calculating a full cost and revenue stream model, and identifying key partnership and key business activities.  

ICORP Interviews:

We interviewed over 110 professionals in the manufacturing area. Among the companies we interviewed are: 3M, Zyvex, Intel, KLA-Tencor, LAM Research, Applied Materials, Lookhead Martin, ZEISS,  etc. We also learned from professional organizations such as SEMI and OSA.

During the interviewing process, we understood the market needs for R2R and R2S Manufacturing. There is a need for faster and more efficient metrology in the current manufacturing (R2R) Market in the US. We were invited and presented our technology to three small (Smart Material Solutions) /medium (Novacentrix) /large (3M) size businesses; and identified three joint development partners (national and international companies) who are eager to collaborate and guide the development of the system. As an additional honor, we were awarded the Cohort Award of the National ICORP Teams. 

Results:

During the course of the ICORP Program, we were able to:

  • Develop a full market analysis
  • Develop a Canvas Model
  • Interview over 110 companies in the R2R/R2S and Wafer-Scale Manufacturing Area
  • Were invited to present our work to International Companies (3M, Novacentrix)
  • Were invited to publish (invited paper) on professional organizations (including SPIE)
  • Applied to NSF following Grants such as PFI
  • Create partnership with international and national private and public companies

Conclusions:

During customer discovery in the ICORP National Program, the need for this technology was verified by the large number of national and international companies excited about working with us as partners. We were able to partner with international and national companies to continue developing our technology.

 


Last Modified: 12/17/2021
Modified by: Steven R Brueck
